Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 52102-001  
Transaction Technical Assistance Facility (F-TRTA) 
July 2018 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of Bangladesh: Capacity Building 
for Improving Portfolio Performance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
____________________________ 
 
Distribution of this document is restricted until it has been approved by the Board of Directors. 
Following such approval, ADB will disclose the document to the public in accordance with ADB’s 
Public Communications Policy 2011.

  CCGP  –  Cabinet Committee on Government Purchase 
  CDRC  –  capacity development resource center

  TAPP  –  technical assistance project proforma

NOTES 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of the Government of Bangladesh ends on 
30 June. “FY” before a calendar year denotes the year in which the fiscal year 
ends, e.g., FY2017 ends on 30 June 2017. 
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  Wencai Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  Hun Kim, South Asia Department (SARD)

TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY AT A GLANCE

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The Economic Relations Division (ERD), under the Ministry of Finance, and several 
executing agencies have requested ADB on various occasions, including during tripartite portfolio 
review meetings (TPRM), for a systematic capacity development program to enhance quality of 
project implementation and management, and project readiness. Given the growing portfolio with 
higher complexity and relatively low project readiness, ADB’s hands-on support is essential for 
successful project implementation. Hence, a TRTA facility is proposed to provide project specific 
implementation support as well as the institutional capacity development in a systematic manner.  
 
2.  The transaction technical assistance (TRTA) facility1 will provide implementation support 
to a series of ongoing and ensuing projects.2  In addition, the facility will support capacity 
development of line ministries and executing agencies, and project review and monitoring for 
improving the portfolio performance. The TRTA facility builds on the lessons learned from the 
implementation of ongoing TA 8426-BAN: Capacity Building for Portfolio Management approved 
on 13 August 2013, which is closing on 31 December 2018.3 Scope of TA 8426 is limited to 
supporting portfolio review and monitoring, and short-term capacity development and trainings. 
The purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and terms of 
references of the TRTA were discussed with the ERD.4 Key areas of support needs are detailed 
in the following paragraphs. 
 
3.  Portfolio-wide support. ADB’s ongoing portfolio in Bangladesh has grown rapidly over 
the past few years. Current ongoing portfolio amount stands at $8.5 billion and consists of 87 
loans and grants for 52 projects.5 The portfolio will continue to grow as ADB’s annual lending to 
Bangladesh is expected to grow to $2.1 billion in 2018 from $1.3 billion in 2017. However, slow 
procurement process, project start-up delays and lengthy process for approval and revision of 
development project proforma (DPP) and technical assistance project proforma (TAPP) are often 
hampering the project implementation, resulting in time and cost overruns. Among the 52 ongoing 
ADB supported projects, over 15% are aged more than seven years, 10% were extended twice, 
and 20% were extended for more than two years. The DPPs above Tk500 million (approximately 
$6 million) require approval of Executive Committee of the National Economic Council (ECNEC).6 
TAPPs above Tk100 million (approximately $1.2 million) require approval of the minister/state 
minister of planning. All procurement packages above Tk1,000 million (approximately $12 million) 
and consultancy contracts above Tk300 million (approximately $3.6 million) have to be approved 
by the Cabinet Committee on Government Purchase (CCGP). The ECNEC and CCGP approvals 
are process intensive. The weak due diligence capacity of line ministries and executing agencies 
often result in delays in preparation, revision and approval of DPPs/TAPPs. To reduce project 
                                                
1   The proposed TRTA is not included in the ADB 2018 country operations business plan, Bangladesh, 2018 -2020. 
The Economic Relations Division, Government of Bangladesh has been consulted with, and it has endorsed the 
processing of TRTA. The South Asia Regional Department confirmed that such financial assistance can be 
accommodated in 2018 resource envelope.  
2   Ongoing projects include Greater Dhaka Sustainable Urban Transport Project (Loan 2862/63/64), Skills for 
Employment Investment Program –Tranche 1 and 2 (Loan 3131/3468/Grant 0391/0517), and projects from 
agriculture and natural resources and transport sectors. The TRTA will also support ensuing projects on need basis.  
3   TA 8426-BAN: Capacity Building for Portfolio Management, August 2013. 
4   ERD confirmation was received on 16 April 2018. 
5   As of 20 June 2018. 
6   The minister/state minister of planning has the authority to approve DPPs up to Tk500 million (approx. $6 million). 
The authority for project revision by the relevant minister/state minister is limited to first revision with some 
conditions. In case of approval of TAPPs, the ministerial ceiling is up to Tk100 million (approx. $1.2 million).

2   
lead  time,  capacity  of  executing  agencies  needs  to  be  strengthened  and  expedite  the 
DPPs/TAPPs and CCGP process.  
 
4.  Procurement capacity support. ADB’s country partnership strategy for Bangladesh 
(CPS 2016-2020)7 prioritizes investment in infrastructure such as energy, transport and urban 
development, and help the country’s rapid economic growth. Accordingly, ADB’s assistance in 
recent years has focused on large and complex projects. The contract sizes have grown, and 
there are several ongoing contracts valued more than $100 million. However, weak capacity of 
executing and implementing agencies to handle complex and diverse projects has been a 
concern. While concerted efforts supported by the government and development partners to 
develop institutional capacity are ongoing, progress is incremental. Hence, the CPS (2016-2020) 
envisages  more  project-based  assistance  on  procurement  and  project  implementation  by 
providing on-the-job training with direct oversight of result and outcome. In addition, stronger 
support is needed in application of ADB’s Procurement Policy 2017 and Procurement Regulations 
for ADB Borrowers 2017 (as amended from time to time). 
 
5.  Institutional capacity and governance. Institutional capacity and governance are also 
the priority cross-cutting areas identified by CPS (2016-2020) for enhancing the effectiveness of 
ADB-assisted projects and programs. The CPS (2016-2020) recommends providing systematic 
institutional capacity support over a longer period and more targeted than general.  
 
6.  Financial management. Timely preparation and submission of year-end audited project 
financial statements (APFS) following international accounting standards are essential for sound 
public financial management and good governance. Support to strengthen country systems, 
implementation and monitoring mechanism of financial management action plan, and fiduciary 
reviews in weaker and decentralized sectors are critical. ADB is supporting the executing and 
implementing agencies for improving the financial management and resolution of audit issues. 
However, the audit exit meeting for FY2017 shows that out of 1,034 audit observations for ADB 
supported projects, only 415 or 45% were resolved, 11% more than the previous year (34% in 
FY2016). ADB’s oversight and technical support on resolution of audit issues needs to be 
strengthened. More collaboration with Foreign Aided Project Audit Directorate (FAPAD) is needed 
to improve the quality of audit as per international standard of auditing (ISA) and international 
standard of supreme audit institutions (ISSAI). Current accounting systems in most of the ADB 
funded projects are standalone, and government’s ongoing roll-out plan of unified accounting 
software needs support at project level. 
 
7.  Project implementation support. On the project specific case, Loan-2862/63/64/Grant-
0287(BAN): Greater Dhaka Sustainable Urban Transport Project,8 a complex project, has several 
implementation challenges, such as delays in review of engineering designs, land acquisition and 
inter-agency coordination. Project completion date has been revised to December 2020, but this 
remains a challenge. Moreover, project start-up has been delayed by more than three years. 
Among the four consultancy packages under the project, contract of operational design and 
business model (ODBM) was closed in December 2017 without completing the envisaged outputs. 
The consultant completed only two of the three outputs. It delivered (i) bus rapid transit (BRT) 
                                                
7   ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: Bangladesh, 2016–2020. Manila. 
8  Project is approved in April 2012 with planned completion by 2015. However, project has been delayed by 3 years. 
Procurement of major civil works is completed only in 2017 as opposed to the planned 2014. The major component 
—construction of bus rapid transit corridor which was planned to start in Q1-2013 could start only in Q2-2017, 
causing a delay of more than three years. The loans have been extended by three years up to December 2020. 
Project  is  categorized  A  for  Involuntary  Resettlement,  B  for  Environment  and  C  for  Indigenous  Peoples. 
https://www.adb.org/projects/42169-013/main#project-pds

3 
operational plan and (ii) BRT business model. But, approval of the two reports has been delayed 
due to capacity and resource limitation of implementing agency. A third component under the 
ODBM for ‘negotiation with the existing bus operators to embark into the company model’ has not 
been accomplished. On the other hand, consulting contracts of project management, coordination 
and  capacity  building  (PMCCB);  engineering,  procurement  and  construction  management 
(EPCM); and resettlement plan implementation (RPI) are closing in December 2018. Hence, there 
will be a gap in consultants’ input. Project needs support to (i) review the operational plan and 
business model, (ii) study on integration of BRT with mass rapid transit (MRT) system, (iii) 
negotiation with the existing bus operators to embark into company model, and (iv) project and 
contract management of civil works. The allocated budget for consultancy under the project has 
been exhausted.9  The TRTA will partially fill in the resource gap beyond December 2018. 
 
8.  Similarly, Loan 3131/Grant 0391-BAN - Skills for Employment Investment Program10 
needs improved management of fiduciary risk. Office of Anticorruption and Integrity (OAI) has 
conducted a project procurement related review (PPRR) in 2017.11 The following three issues are 
noted in OAI’s PPRR interim report (i) documents for milestone and stipends payments are 
inadequate, (ii) monitoring of training centers is inadequate and (iii) financial management of 
industry associations is weak. OAI has suggested for improvement in (i) document keeping, (ii) 
review of milestone-based payments for job placements, and (iii) transparency in stipend payment. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Capacity of executing agencies and line ministries improved. The TRTA 
will enhance the project implementation capacity of executing and implementing agencies by 
providing  structured  trainings  and  capacity  building  support  on  procurement;  financial 
management and audit; project management; and cross-cutting issues such as environmental 
and social safeguards, and gender empowerment and social inclusion. The TRTA will also 
support in successful roll out of ADB’s Procurement Policy 2017.  
 
10.  The TRTA will develop a systematic capacity development plan that cuts across the entire 
project cycle. Learning from the experience of capacity development resource center (CDRC) 
established in ADB’s India and Nepal Resident Missions, the TRTA facility will set up a CDRC in 
ADB’s Bangladesh Resident Mission. As part of CDRC activity, survey and capacity assessment 
of executing and implementing agencies will be conducted for training needs assessment. Annual 
training calendar will be developed, and trainings delivered on the areas highlighted in para 9. 
Additional thematic capacity development activities will cover trainings on high level technologies, 
innovation, new business opportunities, project evaluation, climate change and disaster risk 
management, and good governance and anticorruption measures. Training materials prepared 
by ADB’s India and Nepal Resident Missions may be referred as appropriate. E-learning modules 
of the trainings will be developed. A CDRC website12 will be maintained to share the training 
materials and e-learning activities. The website will also maintain trainees database and facilitate 
communication with the trainees. A mobile based application of the website will also be developed. 
                                                
9   Four consultant contracts include (i) PMCCB -$1.274 million, (ii) EPCM -$4.112 million, (iii) ODBM - $0.872 million, 
and (iv) RPI - $0.135 million. 
10  Approved on 3 Jun 2014 for $100 million, co-financed by World Bank ($79 million); revised closing date 30 Jun 
2019. Project is categorized C for Involuntary Resettlement, C for Environment and B for Indigenous Peoples. 
https://www.adb.org/projects/42466-015/main 
11  OAI’s PPRR missions were fielded on 20 August - 7 September 2017 and 13 November - 6 December 2017, and 
exit meeting was held on 12 December 2017. 
12  Website developed by TRTA will follow the Guidelines on Social Media at ADB and the Branding Tool Kit.

4   
11.  The TRTA facility will engage a CDRC Team Leader / Training Coordinator. In addition to 
sector and thematic staff from ADB, a roster of external (international and national) resource 
persons will be maintained to deliver the trainings.13 The external resource persons will be 
engaged on need basis. The CDRC will train approximately 500 officials from various executing 
and implementing agencies. Overseas trainings for up to 50 government officials will be organized 
based on the demand and needs assessment. The CDRC may support the executing and 
implementing agencies for certified or accredited short-term trainings, as appropriate. 
 
12.  Output 2. Projects successfully implemented. Implementation of series of ongoing and 
ensuing projects on procurement, safeguards, financial management, project implementation and 
contract management will be supported. The TRTA will recruit international consultants to support 
implementation of Greater Dhaka Sustainable Urban Transport Project (Loan 2862/63/64/Grant 
0287-BAN). The consultants will support to (i) review the operational plan and business model, 
(ii) study integration of BRT with MRT subprojects, (iii) negotiate with existing bus operators to 
embark into company model, and (iii) ensure engineering due diligence of civil works.14  Loan 
3131/Grant 0391-BAN: Skills for Employment Investment Program will be supported for improving 
the financial management and mitigating the fiduciary risk. In addition, TRTA will support at least 
five ongoing or ensuing projects in different sectors on project implementation on need basis. 
 
13.  Output 3: Portfolio performance effectively reviewed and monitored. To enhance the 
operational effectiveness of ADB’s portfolio, the TRTA will help strengthen portfolio review and 
monitoring. The TRTA will support at least five TPRMs and three business opportunities seminars. 
It will support implementation of various actions agreed in the TPRMs. Trainings and IT support 
to  roll-out  procurement  activity  monitoring  tool  (PAMT)  developed  in  Bangladesh  Resident 
Mission in 2018 will be provided to all projects for improved monitoring of procurement activities.15  
The TRTA will develop a quality management system as per International Organization for 
Standardization (ISO: 9001-2015).16 Annual portfolio performance of Bangladesh for 2018 will be 
prepared to assess the portfolio performance and make recommendation for improvement. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $1.6 million, of which $1.5 million equivalent will be financed 
on a grant basis from ADB’s technical assistance fund (TASF - 6) while the government will 
provide the rest as counterpart support in kind, such as data, staff time, venues for meetings and 
events, review of the reports submitted by consultants, and participation in trainings, workshops 
and knowledge sessions. The cost estimate and financing plan is in Appendix 1 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TRTA. In consultation with ERD, and executing and implementing 
agencies, the overall framework program structure and outputs will be finalized. Bangladesh 
Resident Mission will recruit, supervise and evaluate the consultants, and procure the goods.  
 
 
 
                                                
13   Travel cost of ADB staff acting as a resource person will be supported by TRTA, as appropriate. 
14  The DMFs of the projects are updated to reflect the outputs and activities of the TRTA. The updated versions will 
be incorporated in the project administration manuals of the respective projects. 
15   PAMT is a web-based database (www.bdpamt.org) that records, monitors the time taken at each step of 
procurement process, and tracks and alerts the delays. 
16   ISO 9001:2015 - quality management system certification will help ADB achieving the high standard operation.

5 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

ADB = Asian Development Bank, QCBS = quality and cost-based selection, TRTA = transaction technical assistance 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.17 The TRTA will be implemented by international and national individual 
consultants (20 person-months for international and 84 person-months for national). Additional 
consultants may be recruited as needed. Given the diverse nature of deliverables, the consultants 
will be recruited individually on need basis. Equipment will be procured using RFQ procedure 
according to ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. Consulting services will commence in 
October 2018 and continue full time as well as on intermittent basis till June 2021. 
 
18.  CDRC Team Leader / Training Coordinator will duly consult with ERD, and executing and 
implementing agencies; and produce an inception report within two months of commencement 
stipulating the overall work plan. Training materials will be printed locally and posted on CDRC’s 
website.  CDRC  Team Leader  / Training  Coordinator  will  prepare  CDRC’s  annual  capacity 
development report. Improvement in portfolio performance, information on number of training 
programs  conducted,  feedback  from  participants,  best  practices,  and  sector  and  thematic 
knowledge products will be included in the report. The report will be published on CDRC website. 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bangladesh for Capacity Building for Improving Portfolio Performance, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
17  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
